pageContext.patina: Traces of black patina with d. bronze showing through.
pageContext.surface: Smooth. Appears to have been scraped. A little light earth on one side of blade.
pageContext.other: Width: blade 71mm; socket 24.5mm,Thickness: socket 25mm; blade 4mm; 16mm,Weight: 396.88 gms
pageContext.publications: Geo. Robberton in a letter to Major Bunny, dated 16.12.1873 (from Anatomical Dept. Mus. Oxford) asks for permission to describe them in a short paper for the Newbury Field Club.,Evans, J., Anc. Bronze Impl. 337,Proc. Soc. Ant. 2nd Ser. v. 404, pl. III.II,V.C.H. Berks, i. 195,Hist. of Newbury and Environs, 142, fig.,Arch. Assoc. Journ. XVI, 322, pl. XXVI.4,Trans. Newbury Dist. Field Club, ii. 124-5.
pageContext.collection: Lieut. Col. E. J. St. John, Slinfold
pageContext.site: England,Berkshire,Speen,("in the Speen Moor, Valley of the Kennet, in the peat")
pageContext.remarks: "Professor Robberton of Oxford pronounces them to have undoubtedly belonged to the Ancient Britons."
